Comment: From our report:  Leavenworth, Kansas, [is a prison town](https://www.travelks.com/kansas-magazine/articles/post/the-lore-of-kansas-first-city-leavenworth/). ... But there’s one prison [local officials aren’t interested in](https://kansasreflector.com/2025/04/06/this-kansas-town-knows-prisons-it-doesnt-want-a-for-profit-company-opening-a-hell-hole-for-ice/): An immigration detention center that private prison operator CoreCivic has proposed. The controversy over the proposal is indicative of a tension playing out across the country as the Trump administration’s mass deportation agenda bumps up against [practical limitations in detention bed space](https://www.reuters.com/world/us/us-immigration-detention-maxed-out-47600-detainees-ice-official-says-2025-03-12/).  ... The nation’s detention facilities were maxed out last month, according to the Department of Homeland Security, and The Washington Post reported that in some overcrowded facilities, [detainees are being forced to sleep on the floor](https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2025/04/18/immigrant-detention-overcrowding-trump-crackdown/). At the Krome North Service Processing Center in Miami, The Associated Press reports that staff fear an “uprising” as the population [has soared to nearly three times capacity](https://apnews.com/article/immigration-miami-deportation-detention-ice-67a6c798b56ea4b42ee06afcc8c22428).  Despite the crunch, it’s not clear that communities around the country are clamoring to host facilities. In Lincoln County, Wyoming — where Trump [won by nearly 70 points in 2024](https://www.kemmerergazette.com/stories/2024-general-election-unofficial-results,49599) — the local community has also rebuffed efforts to construct an immigration detention center in the area, at least in part due to concerns that [the federal government has become a less reliable contract partner](https://wyofile.com/kemmerer-balks-at-immigration-jail-as-private-prisons-eye-southwest-wyoming-again/) under Trump and Elon Musk’s DOGE efforts. “We can’t do it, and we don’t want it,” a local politician bluntly told WyoFile.  Efforts to reopen shuttered facilities around the country are well underway in [Michigan](https://www.wzzm13.com/article/news/local/baldwin-prison-ice-detention-center/69-9bd44e29-e6d5-4d69-b73d-367e131a2019), [New Jersey](https://www.cbsnews.com/newyork/news/newark-new-jersey-migrant-detention-facility-reopening/), [Texas](https://apnews.com/article/immigrant-detention-facility-families-texas-dilley-2cd794bdd0b81dca98c8353348fc149b) [and elsewhere](https://stateline.org/2025/04/11/for-profit-immigration-detention-expands-as-trump-accelerates-his-deportation-plans/), often despite the concerns of local politicians and activists. The push is mostly being led by private prison companies as they jockey for new contracts.
